Class Portal

  • java.lang.Object
    • Entity
      • Portal
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Serializable

    public class Portal
extends Entity
    A class representing a Portal. It is visually represented as a blue one-dimensional line of thickness 1. The length of the Portal can be specified.

    Though Entities can enter the Portal from either direction, it will only deposit exiting Entities in the forward facing direction. For example, if the Portal is at a rotation of 0 radians, it looks like a vertical line, and it deposits Entities towards the right.

    Portals preserve relative angles. If two Portals are at an angle to each other, then Entities entering one Portal will emerge rotated from the other Portal such that the relative position of either Portal remains the same.

    Needless to say, two Portals are necessary for desired functionality. Call the setTarget(Portal) method of both Portals to link them together. Note that it is possible to have one-way Portals.

    Author:
    Jiayin Huang, Tony Cui, Sally Hui
    See Also:

      • notifyCollision

        public void notifyCollision(Entity instigator)
        Teleports the instigator Entity over to the target portal, if one is set. Invokes the ensureNoCollision(Entity) method in Spacetime to ensure that the Entity does not materialize on top of another Entity. Ah, the bane of teleportation.
        Overrides:
        notifyCollision in class Entity
        Parameters:
        instigator - the Entity that caused the collision
        See Also:
        Entity.resolveCollision(java.util.List<Entity>, double, double, double)

      • setTarget

        public void setTarget(Portal portal)
        Sets the target Portal for this Portal. Note that it is possible to have a one-way Portal. If a two-way Portal is desired, you must add this Portal to the other Portal and vice versa. It is possible to have the two Portals in separate Spacetime objects.
        Parameters:
        portal - the Portal that this Portal will lead to
